C0D7CA05226E41FE9E0FD682E5A3C293.description: Investigate how humans from various cultures use earth materials to make objects.

4F2FDCBB7A5C4F14B7D06E0A4ACDFBCD.description: Recognize that gravitational, magnetic, and electrostatic forces can move certain objects without touching them directly.

3F2618F03851499DABEB965A272921BF.description: Identify ways in which problems associated with static electricity can be avoided or eliminated.

9E2654688CAB4294B589D83A64BB9E45.description: Predict and test to identify materials that are attracted by magnets and those that can be magnetized.

197FB1D6400D4CD4900A579025481343.description: Recognize that force is a push or pull and that attraction and repulsion are types of pushes and pulls.

10C49F1BBFAD415AB5D96126D95E1928.description: Use appropriate vocabulary related to their investigations of forces.

290C189B63E64C3286F0A07BFD686F84.description: Evaluate simple structures to determine if they are safe and appropriate to the user.

0303ACC7BB824E27BBBB5B7937F2E5F9.description: Describe the effects of various forces on different structures.

F76DB7A551A54461AF511B6C1D558852.description: Identify shapes that are part of natural and human-built structures from various cultures and describe how these shapes help to provide strength and stability.

DFE2C4D525C745A4A3B8BA05371124E0.description: Use the design process to construct an environment that enhances plant growth.

072F450626164F9EAE1A546CF17C2A9F.description: Conduct experiments to determine conditions needed for healthy plant growth.

0F8A3FFD8A924A98AE1BE3F9305C1045.description: Show respect for plants as living things.

6C73F88BB1F64FB38B8EF78FCCCD1651.description: Observe, compare, and contrast the structure and appearance of several types of plants.

27924E73BCE94BC7A52A7104442D3A2F.description: Use appropriate vocabulary related to their investigations of growth and changes in plants.

15A26E02DEC14CC7A4D40BE77753CEF5.description: Take the time to repeat a measurement or observation for greater precision or detail.

80464A8C83074FA38F0AC3A0F5B966BC.description: Express enjoyment when sharing and discussing science-related experiences from daily life.

1F5D03115B594B9DB00D398B98535629.description: Listen to and consider differing opinions.

75253645F2884335BAFB5E07BECB6844.description: Recognize that scientists develop explanations from observations and what they already know about the world, and that good explanations are based on evidence.

E9A3E38024694E4381BBCA85069ED3BE.description: Recognize that valid experiments normally have reproducible results, which may vary slightly

F9C12E0A89834592BFC282B1E58D097D.description: Communicate results and conclusions in a variety of ways.

745E034B1A0C44798A492169CC76FB71.description: Explain why conclusions related to classroom experiments should be based on multiple trials or classroom data rather than on an individual result.

11A236F3A2974A1CBD2441C1677579B3.description: Make observations that are relevant to a specific question

12167D06332C4F9184BB6D02B2A891BF.description: Assume roles and share responsibilities as group members.

79E58D5787E04B2DA3E5F2C6974D49B8.description: Create, with the class, a plan to answer a given question.

C8E0BDE6C3694D4DBF125FDA3D7F1782.description: Ask questions that lead to investigations of living things, objects, and events in the local environment.
